title: BTN Open (RFI)
description: Which hands should you open-raise from the Button when folded to you?
scenario: Folded to you on the Button. Standard 100BB deep cash game.
explanation: The Button is the most profitable position at the table because you always have position postflop. This allows for a very wide opening range of ~45% of hands. You should open all pocket pairs, most suited aces, broadway hands, suited connectors, and many suited one-gappers. The key principle is that position compensates for raw hand strength.

title: UTG Open (RFI)
description: Which hands should you open-raise from Under The Gun?
scenario: You are Under The Gun at a 6-max table. Standard 100BB deep.
explanation: UTG is the tightest opening position because you have 5 players left to act who could have strong hands. Your range should be ~18% of hands — premium pairs, strong broadways, and select suited connectors for balance. Note how suited connectors like 76s-T9s are included for board coverage but weak offsuit hands are excluded.

title: BB Defend vs BTN Open
description: Which hands should you defend from the Big Blind against a Button open?
scenario: Button raises to 2.5BB, Small Blind folds. You are in the Big Blind.
explanation: The BB gets an excellent price to defend (calling 1.5BB to win 4BB = 2.67:1 odds), allowing a very wide defending range of ~55%. You already have 1BB invested. Defend with almost all suited hands, most offsuit broadways, suited connectors, and even some weak suited hands. Premium hands (QQ+, AK) should be 3-bet instead of flat called.

title: CO 3-Bet vs BTN
description: Which hands should you 3-bet with from the Cutoff against a Button open?
scenario: You are in the Cutoff. The Button raises to 2.5BB.
explanation: 3-betting from the CO vs BTN is a mix of value (TT+, AQs+, AKo) and bluffs (A5s/A4s for blockers, suited connectors for board coverage). This is a tighter 3-bet range because the BTN opens wide and can flat in position. The ace-blocker hands reduce the chance villain has AA/AK, making them ideal bluff candidates.

title: SB 3-Bet vs CO
description: Which hands should you 3-bet from the Small Blind against a Cutoff open?
scenario: You are in the Small Blind. The Cutoff raises to 2.5BB. Button folds.
explanation: From the SB, you should 3-bet or fold (rarely flat call, since you'll be out of position). This polarized range includes strong value hands (99+, ATs+) and suited ace bluffs (A3s-A5s). The SB 3-bet range is wider than CO vs BTN because the CO opens tighter than the BTN, but you need to fight for the pot to avoid losing your blind.

title: BB 3-Bet vs UTG
description: Which hands should you 3-bet from the Big Blind against an UTG open?
scenario: UTG raises to 2.5BB. Folds around to you in the Big Blind.
explanation: Against an UTG open, your 3-bet range should be very tight. UTG opens only ~18% of hands, so their range is strong. Your value range is narrow (JJ+, AQs+, AKo) and you add a small number of bluffs (A5s/A4s) for balance. Most other hands should defend by calling, as 3-betting light against a strong range is -EV.

title: HJ Open (RFI)
description: Which hands should you open-raise from the Hijack?
scenario: Folded to you in the Hijack at a 6-max table. Standard 100BB deep.
explanation: The Hijack opens wider than UTG (~25% of hands) but still tighter than CO/BTN. You have 3 players left to act. Include all pocket pairs down to 55, suited broadways, suited connectors, and select offsuit broadways. Hands like 44/33/22 can be marginal opens here — many players mix between opening and folding them.

title: CO Open (RFI)
description: Which hands should you open-raise from the Cutoff?
scenario: Folded to you in the Cutoff. Standard 100BB deep cash game.
explanation: The Cutoff opens roughly ~35% of hands — wider than HJ but slightly tighter than BTN. With only 2 players behind, you can open most pocket pairs, suited aces, suited connectors, and many suited one-gappers. The CO is often called the 'second-best seat' because you frequently end up with position when the BTN folds.
